etymologies: late Middle English: via Old French from Latin licentia ‘freedom, licentiousness’ (in medieval Latin ‘authority, permission’), from licere ‘be lawful or permitted’

definitions: a permit from an authority to own or use something, do a particular thing, or carry on a trade (especially in alcoholic beverages)
formal or official permission to do something

examples.text: logging is permitted under license from the Forest Service

definitions: a writer's or artist's freedom to deviate from fact or from conventions such as grammar, meter, or perspective, for effect
shortDefinitions: writer's freedom to deviate from fact

definitions: freedom to behave as one wishes, especially in a way that results in excessive or unacceptable behavior

examples.text: the government was criticized for giving the army too much license

definitions: a reason or excuse to do something wrong or excessive

examples.text: police say that the lenient sentence is a license to assault

definitions: grant a license to (someone or something) to permit the use of something or to allow an activity to take place

examples.text: brokers must be licensed to sell health-related insurance
he ought not to have been licensed to fly a plane

shortDefinitions: grant license to person or thing to permit use of something

definitions: authorize the use, performance, or release of (something)

examples.text: the drug is already licensed for human use
he was required to delete certain scenes before the film could be licensed for showing

shortDefinitions: authorize use, performance, or release of

definitions: give permission to (someone) to do something

examples.text: he was licensed to do no more than send a message

shortDefinitions: give permission to someone to do something
